content.statement: vascular:venous:cvd-005-atrophie-blanche is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Venous that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:venous:cvd-005-atrophie-blanche helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:venous:cvd-005-atrophie-blanche include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:venous:cvd-005-atrophie-blanche.

presentation: Located in gaiter area, especially perimalleolar
May precede ulcer development or represent healed microvascular events
differential_diagnosis: Healed venous ulcer (different morphology, larger, scar tissue)
Radiation dermatitis (history of radiation, different distribution)
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on characteristic appearance
Duplex ultrasound to document venous disease
Biopsy if atypical or livedoid vasculopathy suspected
Hypercoagulable workup if livedoid vasculopathy suspected
Antiphospholipid antibody testing in appropriate clinical context
treatment: Wound care for any ulceration within lesions
Protect from trauma - very fragile skin

definition.@value: Ivory-white, atrophic, stellate scars of the lower leg surrounded by hyperpigmentation and telangiectasias, resulting from dermal microangiopathy and capillary thrombosis, typically in the setting of chronic venous hypertension.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Distinguish atrophie blanche from other white skin lesions
Understand the microangiopathy underlying atrophie blanche
Identify when to investigate for non-venous causes
clinical_pearls: Atrophie blanche is ivory-white with surrounding hyperpigmentation and telangiectasias
Both venous disease and livedoid vasculopathy can cause identical lesions
Consider hypercoagulable workup if venous disease is minimal
High risk of ulceration - protect from trauma
Antiplatelet therapy may benefit even in venous disease
